sub_topic: Determining the rank of a matrix
message_2:
To find the rank of the matrix, we need to perform Gaussian elimination to find the row echelon form of the matrix. 

Original matrix:
\begin{bmatrix} 
1 & 2 & 3 \\ 
2 & 4 & 6 \\
3 & 6 & 9 
\end{bmatrix}

Subtract 2 times the first row from the second row, and 3 times the first row from the third row:

\begin{bmatrix} 
1 & 2 & 3 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 
\end{bmatrix}

The row echelon form of the matrix has only one non-zero row. Therefore, the rank of the matrix is 1.
